reviewText:
This game is a great way to learn Hiragana and Katakana letters, if you mind the high level of difficulty. It is a somewhat fast paced educational Rhythm game that uses Hira / Kata letters, and your knowledge of them, to go through levels. You would need skill in timing, memorization, and quick reactions in this game.

For someone who knows (or knew) Hiragana and Katakana before, it is still surprisingly challenging. The challenge lies in your reaction time, and memorization. Sometimes, some letters or characters would appear way too near the actual time you have to input them. I know this adds extra challenge, but I have a feeling this should be adjusted a bit.

For people who are brushing up on their Hira / Kata, this is a great way to remember the basics, and also to distinguish on the differences of how each character sounds. I usually had trouble with my あ's and  お's because they look so similar.

They say that this is a game that anyone can enjoy"
date: now I think that is kind of ballsy to say. I'd say that if you are even remotely interested in Japan or learning new languages
recommended: and also if you are really into fun challenging rhythm games
hoursPlayed:
that's when this game can truly be enjoyed. (This is only my opinion though.)


I bought this immediately as soon as it got on the store
voteText: and I could safely say that it was worth it. If you are interested in learning Hira or Kata

reviewText:
I like it!

Yes, it's pretty hard as far as the button switching goes, but I think seems pretty good at getting your character recognition as instantaneous as possible. That being said, I did in fact grab this as a changeup from the memorization I've already done.

I already know both hiragana and katakana, but I think this helps me in my aim to read them less consciously.

Also I'm not great at rythm games, but the challenge makes it fun.

To the Dev: If you do patch the difficulty down, it would be cool if you put the original difficulty in as a hard mode or somesuch.

Also it seems that the achievements aren't triggering properly.

reviewText:
Updated Reiew: I've changed my review from a thumbs down to a thumbs up. I still think that there are a lot of things that could improve the game itself and believe that the game isn't for everyone, as the game is more like flashcard memorisation with music than a game which will teach you the Japanese alphabets. There is nothing wrong with this if you want to use it to supplement learning the language in school or your own self studies but it's not really geared towards everyone.

As someone who already knows both Hiragana and Katakana here are my thoughts on the gameplay itself:

Pro:
Simplistic play style
Great for learning to memorise characters once you have learned what they are
Developer fixing issues/updating the game
Game runs perfectly with no crashing or errors
Con:
Gives Japanese characters but seems to forget to tell you what the English letter equivalent for it is. You can get the sounds if you click on the characters in the pre-mission screen but would be better to see the written letters. Also been reported an issue if you are using a controller that you can't get the sounds, you must have a mouse currently to do this.
Too much emphasis on memorising patterns of characters instead of teaching the characters themselves
Soundtrack is OK but the SFX are not great, feeling like they will get on your nerves after a couple of hours play. Thankfully you can turn the sound completely off if you feel this way.
Not enough notice given on which characters go to which keys (it randomly changes with each pattern) making the game unnecessarily difficult
Katakana tutorial is the exact same as the Hiragana one (didn't even bother to change characters to Katakana)
If you had more notice on which keys were for which characters, slower tempo for earlier levels to give people who are new to the language more time to adjust to the characters and less emphasis on what the pattern is after it's been flashed to you then the game might be ok but as it is now, it's not great.

reviewText: I saw this game prior to its release and couldn't wait till it was released and the wait was worth it in my opinion.  The game was indeed a bit frustrating at first with the various Hiragana and Katakana switching keys every now and again but that was actually an interesting way to implement learning instead of simply memorization. I came into the game knowing little to nothing about either or and I'm surprised at how quickly I'm picking up Hiragana and Katakana. Overall, If you like rhythm based games with a bit more difficulty then normal and would like to learn Hiragana and/or Katagana then give this one game a try.

reviewText:
Learn japanese (Hiragana and Katakana) symbols by playing?
Fast thinking, memorizing, repeating and getting all those symbols in your head at the same time, while listening to the sound and repeating the same rhythm. Not as easy as it sounds as the layout on the controller is changing constantly to keep you awake.
All the while a nice manga backround is scrolling by.

Update one day later:
Contacted the developer, about the problems I had. One day later and he gave us already an update to those problems. Holy that was smoking fast. Those big indie developers that won't fix their big games, should take it as seriously as these guys here :)

reviewText:
Not perfect, but not terrible.
It's got enjoyable enough gameplay to make it not boring, and somewhat decent music if you like chiptunes (I do). Which is pretty much what you need to do a repetitive task like commiting something to memory.

I dislike all of the levels that require you to remember multiple characters and their order for a while and then play them out. The difficulty curve on this game swings wildly because of seemingly random combinations of variables on how the levels play. It's even worse when on the one level I played it just flashed the hirigana characters before the blocks, and expected you to identify them (as the romaji letters were shown on the keys), AND remember them (because there was nothing printed on the boxes to jump over), made worse because some of them were only shown for a fraction of a second before it flashed the next.
I get that it's good to force you to try to identify them faster, but memory isn't my strongest point and remembering whole words is different to remembering multiple single characters.
Maybe it does serve a roll, but I can't see how and I just find them frustrating.

I've not come accoss a section that I haven't been able to get past though so it's not a big deal, and I still like the rest of the game for what it does. I just wish the boxes always had something printed on them (preferably the romaji characters if the hirigana characters are shown on the keys, or the hirigana characters if the romanji are on the keys)
